title: Is it bad to have different types of songs in an album? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s a matter of opinion. Some people find it distracting to have lots of different styles of song on an album; I find it bracing. Some albums are the better for being wall-to-wall the same kind of thing.  (By Source, Fair use, File:HardDayUK.jpg - Wikipedia) The Beatles’ 1964 A Hard Day’s Night is not only the first Beatles album to contain no cover versions, it’s the only Beatles album to only contain songs by Lennon & McCartney. It’s a big slab of uncut, slam-bang, woo-woo Beatlemania and the album I would recommend to anyone who wanted to get a sense of the early Beatles. I would compare it to an album I wouldn’t normally have listened to but I recently enjoyed: Death’s 1998 The Sound of Perseverance.  (By Source, Fair use, File:DeathSOP-1998.jpg - Wikipedia) It may seem perverse to compare a Beatles album to a death metal album, but really only the sound and lyrical content of the albums are different. They both have similar aesthetic principles (maximum impact, unity of timbre, consistent orchestration from one song to another) and they maintain a consistent mood throughout—with the Beatles it’s upbeat jangly guitar pop, with Death it’s intense death-metal riffage, but deep down, both bands are trying to make the same kind of album. But the Mothers of Invention’s 1969 Weasels Ripped My Flesh is, like most of the albums Frank Zappa oversaw, a series of stylistic shocks:  (By Source, Fair use, File:Frank Zappa Weasels Ripped My Flesh.jpg - Wikipedia) The opening track, ‘Didja Get Any Onya?’, is a live recording of the Mothers playing and goofing around and reciting bizarre dialogue. The second track, a cover of Little Richard’s ‘Directly From My Heart To You’, is a devastating blues with a brilliant performance by Don ‘Sugarcane’ Harris on vocals and electric violin. The next track, ‘Prelude to the Afternoon of a Sexually Aroused Gas Mask’, is different again. And so on. One of my favourite albums is, like Zappa’s work, deliberately constructed to jolt the listener out of torpor and be unpredictable, albeit for different reasons than Zappa’s dada-inspired sense of fun: Robert Fripp’s 1979 debut solo album Exposure.  (Cover art can be obtained from Discipline Global Mobile.Fair use, File:Robert Fripp-Exposure (album cover).jpg - Wikipedia) Exposure was Fripp’s only attempt as a solo musician to make something like a pop album, and it’s one of the strangest albums ever made, although nearly 40 years on it still sounds fresh and, in its forebodings about environmental disaster, even prophetic. Fripp doesn’t sing on it; he hired Daryl Hall to be the main singer, but Hall’s management made such a fuss about Hall’s involvement that Fripp ended up substituting Terre Roche and Peter Hammill on many of the vocal tracks Hall had originally recorded. Peter Gabriel appears on it too, Fripp having produced Gabriel’s second solo album. (There are multiple versions of Exposure knocking about, at this point, but I’ll describe the 1985 version, which is the one I first encountered.) The album has been called ‘the punk Sgt. Pepper’ and for all that it has roots in prog, experimental music, soul and Fripp’s own rather outré intellectual influences, there’s something in that; it was made after he’d emerged from his mid-70s adult education period and had been hanging around the NYC clubs marvelling at bands like Television and Blondie. It’s easiest to briefly describe what each track in Exposure is like Preface: A brief audio recording of Brian Eno in a New York City falafel restaurant, saying ‘Can I play you…some of the new things I’ve been doing, which I think…could be commercial.’ The background chat and clink of plates, etc., cuts out. A phone rings, and keeps ringing. A door opens. Footsteps walk across the stereo picture and the phone is picked up. Sound of a guitar down the phone, playing the ner-ner-ner-ner opening riff of:You Burn Me Up I'm a Cigarette: Frenetic three-chord punk song, sung not entirely convincingly by Hall, featuring Fripp’s own lyrics. (Most of the lyrics on the album are by his then-girlfriend Joanna Walton.)Breathless: Intricate, leisurely prog-metal in weird time signature with very difficult riffs.Disengage: Angry rock song with shrieky vocals by Hammill.North Star: Airy and beautiful lilting ballad with fantastic Hall vocal.Chicago: Grungy sort-of blues with another tortured Hammill vocal.NY3: Lurching metal instrumental, a distant cousin of Hendrix’s ‘Foxy Lady’, with dialogue recorded and looped by Fripp of a bitter family argument in his neighbour’s apartment in NYC. (Sample dialogue, mother to daughter: ‘You gotta go for an abortion, baby, I never had to!’)Mary: Charming quasi-acoustic ballad with very nice vocal by Roche, tracking Hall’s original vocal; Hall improvised the melody and Roche re-recorded it after Hall’s management made a fuss.Exposure: Weird funk track, a cover of the same track from Peter Gabriel’s second album, with Gabriel muttering the letters in the word ‘exposure’ on each beat while Roche shrieks the title word over and over again.Hååden Two: Grungy, churning, stop-time instrumental with vocal snippets between cycles of the chord progression—one is, amusingly enough, Eno commenting ‘Incredibly dismal, pathetic chord sequence.’Urban Landscape: Haunting, quiet soundscape of Frippertronics, Fripp’s tape-delay system which was first used on his an Eno’s No Pussyfooting album. Slams right into:I May Not Have Had Enough of Me but I've Had Enough of You: Thrashing rock song with a gritty riff and a duet between Hammill and Roche as a duelling couple singing variations on the phrase ‘That is the way it is’, with celestial interlude featuring the title phrase.First Inaugural Address to the I.A.C.E. Sherborne House: Supposedly this is an entire lecture by the author and educator J.G. Bennett, condensed down to seven seconds long. It sounds like a brief burst of white noise.Water Music I: Bennett again, talking in his hesitant, gentle way about global warming and the imminent inundation of cities.Here Comes the Flood: Wonderful piano-ballad version by Gabriel of a song originally recorded as bombastic power ballad on his first solo album; this is far better, with just his voice and piano and some tasteful synth by Eno.Water Music II: Lush, post-apocalyptic Frippertronics. Long fade into silence. Followed by:Postscript: Eno again in the restaurant, saying with evident amusement ‘So the whole story is completely untrue…a big hoax,’ and chuckling. ‘A big hoax’ is then heard looped and filtered, as if down a telephone, then the phone is put down, footsteps travel across the stereo from right to left, and a door slams shut.Like I said: a weird album. But certainly not one that lets you sit back and bask in a mood. It forces you to engage with it. So, it’s not necessarily bad to have different types of songs in an album. I would, however, argue that it is bad to promise that you will have different types of songs in an album, and then not make good on that. Or, conversely, to strive for a consistent feel, and then end up making something that’s all over the place (or boring.)

Sometimes, it can be; The White Album, for example, covers way too much ground, not all of it necessarily in keeping with the Beatles’ history up to that point. I think variety can work if it develops an artist’s sound; the most obvious examples I’m aware of would be The Fragile by Nine Inch Nails and Soundtracks for the Blind by Swans. With The Fragile, there’s enough ambient tracks to constitute a genuine shift in mood and dynamic from NIN’s previous albums, but there are enough industrial rock/metal songs that it can still be considered an industrial rock album, albeit one with strong art rock elements. Soundtracks for the Blind, on the other hand, contains a bit of every genre Swans had dabbled in up to that point; industrial, goth rock, noise rock, folk, and so on. However, that album had something new to contribute; there were some ambient tracks, and some songs had enough focus on the instrumental palette that they could probably be considered post-rock. It’s a celebration of Swans history, while also further developing Swans’ sound, and foreshadowing the drone and post-rock antics they would get up to in the current decade.
